issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: All attempts at reproducing this issue failed, or not enough information was available to reproduce the issue. Reading the code produces no clues as to why this behavior would occur. If more information appears later, please reopen the issue.
resolution.name: Cannot Reproduce

fields.summary: Rescan SCSI bus to remap LUN assignments

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

fields.summary: Rescan SCSI bus to remap LUN assignments

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description:
The discussion of this condition started in EUCA-3624 but it became apparent that in 3.2 the behavior is different. Thus this bug. As [~lwade] pointed out in the related bug, the following sequence of events, with a NetApp SAN, results in I/O errors:

* create 3 volumes in a NetApp AZ
* attach 3 volumes to one instance
* detach 1 of the volumes

From then on, the volume can be attached and detached multiple times to reproduce the error. On each detach, the errors (in {{dmesg}} and in {{/var/log/messages}}) look as follows:

{code}
Feb 26 16:42:28 g-19-04 kernel: sd 6:0:0:3: [sdf] Warning! Received an indication that the LUN assignments on this target have changed. The Linux SCSI layer does not automaticall
y remap LUN assignments.
Feb 26 16:42:28 g-19-04 kernel: __ratelimit: 128 callbacks suppressed

fields.summary: detaching of volumes correlates with I/O errors in host OS's log

comments.body:
I instrumented the disconnect script on Lester Wade's setup (g-19-04). I found the following, as expected:
{code}
Feb 26 18:32:38 g-19-04 kernel: __ratelimit: 128 callbacks suppressed
Feb 26 18:32:38 g-19-04 kernel: sd 6:0:0:3: [sdf] Result: hostbyte=DID_OK driverbyte=DRIVER_SENSE
Feb 26 18:32:38 g-19-04 kernel: sd 6:0:0:3: [sdf] Sense Key : Illegal Request [current] 
Feb 26 18:32:38 g-19-04 kernel: sd 6:0:0:3: [sdf] Add. Sense: Logical unit not supported
Feb 26 18:32:38 g-19-04 kernel: sd 6:0:0:3: [sdf] CDB: Read(10): 28 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 40 00
Feb 26 18:32:38 g-19-04 kernel: __ratelimit: 128 callbacks suppressed
Feb 26 18:32:38 g-19-04 kernel: __ratelimit: 128 callbacks suppressed
Feb 26 18:32:38 g-19-04 kernel: Buffer I/O error on device sdf, logical block 0
Feb 26 18:32:38 g-19-04 kernel: Buffer I/O error on device sdf, logical block 1
Feb 26 18:32:38 g-19-04 kernel: Buffer I/O error on device sdf, logical block 2
Feb 26 18:32:38 g-19-04 kernel: Buffer I/O error on device sdf, logical block 3
Feb 26 18:32:38 g-19-04 kernel: Buffer I/O error on device sdf, logical block 4
...
{code}
The errors end at 18:32:38 in /var/log/messages.
Now, the interesting part from nc.log:
{code}
2013-02-26 18:32:38 DEBUG 000016241 doDetachVolume           | [i-54343BCF][vol-3AF842ED] volume detaching (localDev=/dev/sdf force=0 grab_inst_sem=1)
2013-02-26 18:32:38 DEBUG 000016241 get_iscsi_target         | invoking `//usr/lib/eucalyptus/euca_rootwrap //usr/share/eucalyptus/get_iscsitarget.pl /,,HBA,3,not_required,,10.105.2.103,iqn.1992-08.com.netapp:sn.142265393`
2013-02-26 18:32:38 DEBUG 000016241 get_iscsi_target         | get storage script returned: 0, stdout: '/dev/sdf', stderr: ''
2013-02-26 18:32:38 DEBUG 000016241 sensor_refresh_resources | polled statistics for 0 instance(s)
2013-02-26 18:32:38 DEBUG 000016241 sensor_refresh_resources | unable to get metrics for instance i-54343BCF (OK if it was terminated---should soon expire from the cache)
2013-02-26 18:32:38 DEBUG 000016241 sensor_expire_cache_entr | invoked
2013-02-26 18:32:38 DEBUG 000016241 get_xpath_content        | failed to parse XML in '/var/lib/eucalyptus/instances/work/ANMUU3T6HV17DCC2C5FVQ/i-54343BCF/vol-3AF842ED-libvirt.xml'
2013-02-26 18:32:38 DEBUG 000016241 doDetachVolume           | [i-54343BCF][vol-3AF842ED] attempting to disconnect iscsi target
2013-02-26 18:32:48 DEBUG 000016241 disconnect_iscsi_target  | disconnect script returned: 0, stdout: '', stderr: 'Starting sleep delay at Tue Feb 26 18:32:38 2013Resuming disconnect at Tue Feb 26 18:32:48 2013Tried deleting lun 0 times
'
{code}
I added the 'Starting sleep delay...' part to the disconnect_iscsitarget_main.pl script that wraps a 10sec sleep of the script before it does anything. So, that gives us a nice separation between the libvirt/KVM operation of detach as issued by the NC and the iscsi operation.

Note the timestamp that the sleep finishes at: 18:32:48. So, the IO errors in /var/log/message are stopping 10seconds before the iscsi disconnect is even being triggered. That tells us that those messages are a result of the KVM detach operation only and have nothing to do with iSCSI LUN mapping etc. I suspect we would see the same results even if we didn't actually do an ISCSI detach and just left the session active. I think this is a KVM issue with how it removes the device from the guest OS.

I'm not sure there is anything we can do about this. We can look at the impact of the virtio drivers as opposed to non-virtio, but I suspect that this is a benign error that indicates that some requests from the guest OS were terminated due to the detach.

At this point, we're seeing actual functional problems, I think this is a non-issue.

Feel free to add any new info you get or correct me if there are functional problems, but for 3.2+ I think we're okay.

The next step is to try the libvirt/KVM detach alone, without any ISCSI change and see if we still find errors in the logs. I can also do just an ISCSI attach/detach without any libvirt/KVM to see if that has similar results.
Link back to EUCA-3624 which was the original, already solved bug.
